channel.title: Fast clean "null" from String[]
channel.description: Your task: write a method that takes a `String[]` and returns a `String[]` which is identical minus any elements containing "null".

item.title: Fast clean "null" from String[]
item.dc:creator: @sppt sppt
item.description:
@sppt wrote:

[quote=“vortex, post:34, topic:454609”]public static String[] cleanStringArrayFromNullStringValues(String inputStringArray[]) { java.util.ArrayList<String> theArrayListThatContainsTheCleanedInputStringArray = new java.util.ArrayList<String>(); for(int inputStringArrayCurrentIndex = 0; inputStringArrayCurrentIndex < inputStringArray.length; inputStringArrayCurrentIndex++) { char inputStringArrayCurrentEntryAsCharArray[] = inputStringArray[inputStringArrayCurrentIndex].toCharArray(); if(inputStringArrayCurrentEntryAsCharArray.length == 4) { if(inputStringArrayCurrentEntryAsCharArray[0] == 'n') { if(inputStringArrayCurrentEntryAsCharArray[1] == 'u') { if(inputStringArrayCurrentEntryAsCharArray[2] == 'l') { if(inputStringArrayCurrentEntryAsCharArray[3] == 'l') { continue; } } } } } theArrayListThatContainsTheCleanedInputStringArray.add(new String(inputStringArrayCurrentEntryAsCharArray)); continue; } String outputStringArray[] = new String[theArrayListThatContainsTheCleanedInputStringArray.size()]; for(int outputStringArrayCurrentIndex = 0; outputStringArrayCurrentIndex < outputStringArray.length; outputStringArrayCurrentIndex++) { outputStringArray[outputStringArrayCurrentIndex] = theArrayListThatContainsTheCleanedInputStringArray.get(outputStringArrayCurrentIndex); continue; } return outputStringArray; }[/quote]
Nice ruler-esque code, 8/10 would definitely read again.

Read full topic

@sinisoul wrote:

[quote=“vortex, post:34, topic:454609”]public static String[] cleanStringArrayFromNullStringValues(String inputStringArray[]) { java.util.ArrayList<String> theArrayListThatContainsTheCleanedInputStringArray = new java.util.ArrayList<String>(); for(int inputStringArrayCurrentIndex = 0; inputStringArrayCurrentIndex < inputStringArray.length; inputStringArrayCurrentIndex++) { char inputStringArrayCurrentEntryAsCharArray[] = inputStringArray[inputStringArrayCurrentIndex].toCharArray(); if(inputStringArrayCurrentEntryAsCharArray.length == 4) { if(inputStringArrayCurrentEntryAsCharArray[0] == 'n') { if(inputStringArrayCurrentEntryAsCharArray[1] == 'u') { if(inputStringArrayCurrentEntryAsCharArray[2] == 'l') { if(inputStringArrayCurrentEntryAsCharArray[3] == 'l') { continue; } } } } } theArrayListThatContainsTheCleanedInputStringArray.add(new String(inputStringArrayCurrentEntryAsCharArray)); continue; } String outputStringArray[] = new String[theArrayListThatContainsTheCleanedInputStringArray.size()]; for(int outputStringArrayCurrentIndex = 0; outputStringArrayCurrentIndex < outputStringArray.length; outputStringArrayCurrentIndex++) { outputStringArray[outputStringArrayCurrentIndex] = theArrayListThatContainsTheCleanedInputStringArray.get(outputStringArrayCurrentIndex); continue; } return outputStringArray; }[/quote]

item.title: Fast clean "null" from String[]
item.dc:creator: @RSCShadow RSCShadow
item.description:
@RSCShadow wrote:

[quote=“Miss Silabsoft, post:17, topic:454609”] function cleanArray(array){ var r = []; for(var s in array){ if(!s.equals("null") && s != null){ r.push(s); } } return r; }
javascript[/quote]You shouldn’t be using for (in) statements on normal arrays since they don’t function like you’re expecting in this snippit. “.equals” isn’t a valid function for a string either which gives an error. Also, you shouldn’t use the double equals (==) in JS, instead use triple equals (===),

function cleanArray(toClean) {
	var result = [];
		
	toClean.forEach(function(element) {
		if(element !== 'null') {
			result.push(element);
		}
	});
		
	return result;
}

EDIT:
A much better version. Don’t know what I was thinking above…

['test', 'tumpty', 'silly', 'null'].filter(function(e) { return e !== 'null'; });

Read full topic

item.title: Fast clean "null" from String[]
item.dc:creator: @TheHolyGrail TheHolyGrail
item.description:
@TheHolyGrail wrote:

[quote=“CodeForFame, post:31, topic:454609”][quote author=TheHolyGrail link=topic=557471.msg4082955#msg4082955 date=1345518818]

[quote author=AtomicInt_ link=topic=557471.msg4079563#msg4079563 date=1345232981]

    public String[] clean(String[] input) {
        for (int i = 0; i < input.length; ++i) {
            input[i] = input[i].replace("null", "");
        }
        return input;
    }

[/quote]Correct except for the fact that your checking if the string literally says “null”. Just change “null” to null.

@management
You’re way off.
[/quote]No he isn’t…

Also, it will not work properly if the string simply has null in it somewhere.

For example:

cleaned will be equivalent to this:

String[] sameAsCleaned = { "", "abc", "def", "", "not" };[/quote]Don’t post if you don’t know what you’re talking about. I clearly stated that he was checking if the string literally said “null”, instead of actually being null. You’re making the same mistake as management, lol.

Do you even know what a null is? Because it sure seems like you don’t.

item.title: Fast clean "null" from String[]
item.dc:creator: @management management
item.description:
@management wrote:

[quote=“AtomicInt_, post:28, topic:454609”][quote author=imthenull link=topic=557471.msg4079603#msg4079603 date=1345235399]

    public String[] clean(String[] input) {
        for (int i = 0; i < input.length; ++i) {
            input[i] = input[i].replace("null", "");
        }
        return input;
    }

This will leave ‘empty’ elements in the array
[/quote]

How? It loops through all the indexes and notes the indexes of the ones that are not “null” then makes a String array the size of the ones that aren’t “null” and then uses the noted indexes to fill it in.

Correct? Or am I missing something here.[/quote]
You are replacing “null” with and empty string, thus leaving emptying elements in the array.

example: clean(new String[] {"hello", "null", "world!"}); //produces "hello", "", "world!"

Read full topic

item.title: Fast clean "null" from String[]
item.dc:creator: @The_Enforcer The Enforcer
item.description:
@The_Enforcer wrote:

Another C++ version that uses raw arrays.

#include <algorithm>
#include <iostream>
#include <string>
#include <cstdlib>

std::string* cleanNull(std::string* const input, const std::size_t inSize, std::size_t& outSize)
{
	outSize = std::partition(input, input + inSize, [] (const std::string& element) -> bool { return element != "null"; }) - input;
	std::string* const result = new std::string[outSize];
	std::copy(input, input + outSize, result);

	return result;
}

int main()
{
	std::string strings[8];
	strings[0] = "one";
	strings[1] = "two";
	strings[2] = "null";
	strings[3] = "four";
	strings[4] = "null";
	strings[5] = "six";
	strings[6] = "null";
	strings[7] = "eight";

	std::size_t outSize = 0;
	const std::string* result = cleanNull(strings, 8, outSize);

	for (std::size_t i = 0; i < outSize; ++i)
	{
		std::cout << result[i] << std::endl;
	}

	delete [] result; result = nullptr;

	std::cin.sync();
	std::cin.get();
	return EXIT_SUCCESS;
}

Read full topic

item.title: Fast clean "null" from String[]
item.dc:creator: @slavemaster veer
item.description:
@slavemaster wrote:

It’d probably be a better idea to use std::array over std::vector here. This would mandate different code that is closer to what is done in Java.

If I were to just use List in Java, the code would merely become…

public static List<String> clean(final List<String> v) { return v.removeAll(Collections.singleton("null")); }

zyle1992:

@veer: What exactly do you mean by “priming” the JVM?

As in trying to ensure it compiles the methods and gets a good “warm-up” first… for example, from this paper…

[b]JVM priming.[/b] The JVM is well known for performing just-in-time compilation and adaptive optimisation of executing bytecode, which can result in fully optimised machine code only being executed at some indeterminate point in the program’s execution. Java programs may therefore be at a disadvantage to those written in other languages, such as C++ or Pascal, where program code is precompiled straight to optimised machine code. One possible means of reducing this disparity would be to “prime” the JVM by executing the Java program many times within the same JVM instance, thus giving it an opportunity toe fully optimise and compile all the code. Care would, however, need to be taken in such an approach to ensure that the user’s program did not store any information for use in successive runs.

Read full topic

item.title: Fast clean "null" from String[]
item.dc:creator: @The_Enforcer The Enforcer
item.description:
@The_Enforcer wrote:

#include <algorithm>
#include <iostream>
#include <string>
#include <vector>
#include <cstdlib>

void cleanNull(std::vector<std::string>& input)
{
	input.erase(std::remove(input.begin(), input.end(), "null"), input.end());
}

int main()
{
	std::vector<std::string> vector;
	vector.push_back("one");
	vector.push_back("two");
	vector.push_back("null");
	vector.push_back("four");
	vector.push_back("five");
	vector.push_back("null");
	vector.push_back("seven");
	vector.push_back("eight");

	cleanNull(vector);

	for (const std::string& element : vector)
	{
		std::cout << element << std::endl;
	}

	std::cin.sync();
	std::cin.get();
	return EXIT_SUCCESS;
}

I used std::vector as it really isn’t modern to use raw arrays in C++ nowadays. As veer modified the original array I see no reason to return anything else.

Read full topic

item.title: Fast clean "null" from String[]
item.dc:creator: @slavemaster veer
item.description:
@slavemaster wrote:

[quote=“zyle1992, post:16, topic:454609”]Total Code:

import java.util.ArrayList;
import java.util.Arrays;

public class TestMain {
    public static void main(String[] args) {
        final String[] input = new String[500];
        for (int i = 0; i < 25; i++) {
            final int randIndex = (int) (Math.random() * input.length);
            input[randIndex] = "Test String";
        }
        long start = System.nanoTime();
        String[] result = cleanWithList(input);
        long delta = System.nanoTime() - start;
        System.out.println("Cleaned array with list in " + delta + "ns");
        
        start = System.nanoTime();
        result = cleanWithCopy(input);
        delta = System.nanoTime() - start;
        System.out.println("Cleaned array with copy in " + delta + "ns");
        
        start = System.nanoTime();
        result = cleanWithChange(input);
        delta = System.nanoTime() - start;
        System.out.println("Cleaned array with change in " + delta + "ns");
    }
    
    public static String[] cleanWithList(final String[] input) {
        final ArrayList<String> list = new ArrayList<String>();
        for (final String s : input) {
            if (s != null) {
                list.add(s);
            }
        }
        return Arrays.copyOfRange(list.toArray(input), 0, list.size());
    }
    
     public static String[] cleanWithCopy(final String[] input) {
        int index = 0;
        final String[] tmp = Arrays.copyOf(input, input.length);
        for (final String s : tmp) {
            if (s != null) {
                tmp[index++] = s;
            }
        }
        return Arrays.copyOfRange(tmp, 0, index);
    }
    
    public static String[] cleanWithChange(String[] input) {
        int index = 0;
        for (final String s : input) {
            if (s != null) {
                input[index++] = s;
            }
        }
        return Arrays.copyOfRange(input, 0, index);
    }
}

Output:

Cleaned array with list in 137941ns
Cleaned array with copy in 40940ns
Cleaned array with change in 25053ns

After repeated tests, the results were about the same (not changing more than 2-5 thousand ns)[/quote]

Why not prime the JVM into compiling the methods to native code? The way you’re doing it right now does not exploit the full potential.

Anyways, here are the ones I came up with…

public static String[] clean(final String[] v) { int r, w; final int n = r = w = v.length; while (r > 0) { final String s = v[--r]; if (!s.equals("null")) { v[--w] = s; } } return Arrays.copyOfRange(v, w, n); }
or

public static String[] clean(final String[] v) { int r, w, n = w = r = v.length; while (r > 0) { final String s = v[--r]; if (!s.equals("null")) { v[--w] = s; } } final String[] c = new String[n -= w]; System.arraycopy(v, w, c, 0, n); return c; }

Arrays.copyOfRange should be avoided when speed is a critical issue since it instantiates the array using reflection.

Read full topic
